name: Madagascar Hissing Cockroach
description: A large cockroach with stunted wings, occurring in two color forms—light brown and nearly black. Males differ from females by larger protuberances behind the head.
image_alt: Madagascar Hissing Cockroach, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
reproduction: It is 'viviparous'—the female carries the ootheca inside her body and releases nymphs when they hatch from the eggs, typically 20−40.
attractions: This flightless species burrows in soil and leaf litter. When disturbed, it emits characteristic hissing sounds, mimicking an agitated snake. The hissing is produced by expelling air through its tracheae. Males also attract females with a loud, far-reaching hiss during courtship.
breeding: We kept these cockroaches in the 1970s in the small animal pavilion; in modern times, we’ve bred them since 2001.
